Robert,

Thank you for the clarification. My mistake. We will have to decide whether
to add a comment suggesting that people not use Test.None or make it a
separate package-visible class.

Sincerely yours,

Kent Beck
Three Rivers Institute

> -----Original Message-----
> From: junit@yahoogroups.com [mailto:junit@yahoogroups.com] On 
> Behalf Of Robert Watkins
> Sent: Saturday, January 21, 2006 5:48 PM
> To: junit@yahoogroups.com
> Subject: Re: [junit] JUnit 4.0 release candidate 2 Test.None
> 
> On 22/01/06, Kent Beck <kentb@...> wrote:
> > Another way to say this is that we needed a Null Object to 
> represent the case where there is no expected exception and 
> you can't use null as a default value. Test.None is package 
> scope, so it shouldn't be publicly accessible, or am I 
> missing something?
> 
> It isn't packaged-scope... in Java, members of an interface always
> have the same visibility as the interface itself (in this case,
> public).
> 
> --
>                "Software is too expensive to build cheaply"
> Robert Watkins           http://twasink.net/
